sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Compromise of 1850. Delaying the Inevitable (1850). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Anna, age 15, from California, 1850.

I'm Anna, fifteen, living in San Francisco. The California Gold Rush has transformed our territory overnight. In 1848, when gold was discovered at Sutter's Mill, California had maybe 14,000 non-Native residents. By 1850, we have over 100,000.
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Anna, fifteen, living in San Francisco.

sections.narration: Henry Clay, now 73 and in failing health, proposes one last compromise to save the Union. He's brokered compromises before—the Missouri Compromise in 1820, the Tariff Compromise in 1833. He's called the "Great Compromiser," though critics say he just postpones inevitable conflicts. Clay's proposal has multiple parts: First, admit California as a free state—what we desperately want.
sections.key_takeaway: Henry Clay, now 73 and in failing health, proposes one last compromise to save the Union.

sections.narration: After months of debate, the Compromise passes in September 1850. California is admitted as the thirty-first state, a free state! We celebrate in San Francisco with parades, speeches, and fireworks. We're Americans now, full members of the Union.
visuals: Chapter title: The Fugitive Slave Act
sections.key_takeaway: After months of debate, the Compromise passes in September 1850.

sections.narration: The compromise's popular sovereignty provision sounds democratic—let settlers decide slavery for themselves. But it's morally bankrupt. Whether human beings can be enslaved shouldn't be decided by majority vote. And it invites conflict, as we'll see when Kansas and Nebraska territories are organized.
sections.key_takeaway: The compromise's popular sovereignty provision sounds democratic—let settlers decide slavery for themselves.

sections.narration: The Compromise of 1850 brings temporary calm. Tensions ease. Talk of secession fades. Many Americans are relieved that catastrophe was averted.
sections.key_takeaway: The Compromise of 1850 brings temporary calm.
